pull.title: doc: Updates how to reproduce fuzz CI failure locally
pull.body: The current version of the doc does not accurately explain how to reproduce a fuzzing CI failure. It seems to imply that you have access to the crash file on CI, and does not describe how to create the file locally and what data to encode.

events.message:
doc: Updates how to reproduce fuzz CI failure locally

The current version of the doc does not accurately explain how to reproduce
a fuzzing CI failure. It seems to imply that you have access to the crash file
on CI, and does not describe how to create the file locally and what data to encode.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--006a51241073e994b41acfe9ec718e94-->
### Code Coverage & Benchmarks
For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/32245.
<!--021abf342d371248e50ceaed478a90ca-->
### Reviews
See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process.
A summary of reviews will appear here.

> The current version of the doc does not accurately explain how to reproduce a fuzzing CI failure. It seems to imply that you have access to the crash file on CI, and does not describe how to create the file locally and what data to encode.

I think the current docs are correct. Generally, the CI iterates over a fixed set of files and those are in a separate repo. The docs apply here.

Only in the rare case, where:

* No fixed set of files has been added yet
* The fuzz target can trigger a crash and reach it in less than 60 seconds from an empty set of files

I'd say it is pretty rare, but if you want to add docs for it, that is fine. Though, I am not sure about removing the existing and correct docs.

I may have missed the point of the section. However, I think there is a missing case in which you are trying to reproduce a fuzzing crash reported by CI that was not part of the corpus, which should be analogous to reproducing a crash case reported by someone else.

I'll undo the changes and add that as an extra section if that makes sense.

Also, the base64 stuff isn't printed for large files. For example https://cirrus-ci.com/task/4877497478676480?logs=ci#L3895:

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -127,15 +127,23 @@ Patience is useful; even with improved throughput, libFuzzer may need days and
 
 ## Reproduce a fuzzer crash reported by the CI
 
-- `cd` into the `qa-assets` directory and update it with `git pull qa-assets`
 - locate the crash case described in the CI output, e.g. `Test unit written to
   ./crash-1bc91feec9fc00b107d97dc225a9f2cdaa078eb6`
+- create a file containing the seed reported right after the crash, e.g. `
+  Base64: Nb6Fc/97AACAAAD/ewAAgAAAAIAAAACAAAAAoA==`
 - make sure to compile with all sanitizers, if they are needed (fuzzing runs
   more slowly with sanitizers enabled, but a crash should be reproducible very
   quickly from a crash case)
-- run the fuzzer with the case number appended to the seed corpus path:
-  `FUZZ=process_message build_fuzz/bin/fuzz
-  qa-assets/fuzz_corpora/process_message/1bc91feec9fc00b107d97dc225a9f2cdaa078eb6`
+- run the fuzzer specifying the crash path:
+  `FUZZ=process_message build_fuzz/bin/fuzz ./crash-1bc91feec9fc00b107d97dc225a9f2cdaa078eb6`

I think you can just add a new bullet point after this one:

```
- If the file does not exist, make sure you are checking out the exact same commit id for the qa-assets repo. If the file was found while running the fuzz engine in the CI, you should be able to reproduce the crash locally with the same (or a similar input) within a few minutes. Alternatively, you can use the base64 encoded file from the CI log, if it exists.
